item.title: Brexit: EU says patience wearing thin with UK in NI border check dispute
item.description: The two sides met as a ban on exporting chilled meat from Great Britain to Northern Ireland looms.

item.title: Covid hospital cases rise above 1,000 in UK
item.description: Scientists say they are still uncertain about the size of a third wave, but vaccination will be key.

item.title: Lockdown easing: Four numbers to look for ahead of the 21 June decision
item.description: The key numbers that offer clues as to whether "freedom day" will proceed as planned on 21 June.

item.title: Covid-19: Highest daily cases since February and 'Glastonbury style' rush for jabs
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Wednesday evening.

item.title: G7 summit: Don't imperil NI peace, Biden to warn UK and EU
item.description: The US president will warn that UK-EU negotiations must protect the Good Friday Agreement, his adviser says.

item.title: Donald Trump-era ban on TikTok dropped by Joe Biden
item.description: The delayed ban on TikTok and WeChat will now not happen - instead apps from China will face reviews.

item.title: Wembley park stabbing deaths: Sisters killed in 'sacrificial deal'
item.description: Danyal Hussein lay in wait before repeatedly stabbing Nicole Smallman and Bibaa Henry, jurors heard.

item.title: Halo Trust: Afghanistan mine clearance workers shot dead 'in cold blood'
item.description: The Islamic State group says it carried out the attack on workers for the Halo Trust.

item.title: Government acted unlawfully over firm's £560,000 Covid contract
item.description: A judge criticises the awarding of work to a firm run by former colleagues of Michael Gove and Dominic Cummings.

item.title: Crocodile attack: British family's fears as saved twin gets sepsis
item.description: The British twins' older sister says Melissa is in a "really serious" condition in hospital in Mexico.

item.title: Harry and Meghan did not ask Queen to use Lilibet name - Palace source
item.description: But a spokesperson for Prince Harry and Meghan insists the Queen was asked, and was supportive.

item.title: Nadine Dorries says women should stand up to doctors
item.description: The health minister says women must be "confident" enough to demand different treatment if they want it.

item.title: Ben Roberts, Derek Conway on The Bill, dies at 70
item.description: The Bangor native played Chief Inspector Derek Conway in the ITV police drama from 1987 to 2002.

item.title: G7: 'Mount Recyclemore' of leaders made from electronic waste in Cornwall
item.description: The sculptor says his work highlights the need to make electronic devices more reusable.

item.title: Dua Lipa revealed as the UK's most-played artist of 2020
item.description: The singer was the biggest presence on UK radio last year, thanks to lockdown anthems like Physical.

item.title: 'We will lose £1,300 unless we get flight refund'
item.description: Customers react as watchdog investigates whether Ryanair and BA broke law in refusing Covid refunds.

item.title: 'My Paralympic dreams dashed by 1.5mm'
item.description: Swimmer Levana Hanson had her sights on a medal – that all changed when she was told one stump too long for her classification.

item.title: Sweet dreams! Wandering elephants take a snooze
item.description: A herd of 15 elephants on the move is China has been spotted having a nap in a forest.

item.title: Why Covid has made it harder for young women to get jobs
item.description: More than 600 million people aged 15-24 are thought to be unemployed, with women most affected.

item.title: Queen's portrait removed after vote by Oxford University students
item.description: Oxford University students vote to remove the image as it is deemed a symbol of "colonial history".

item.title: Free Hugs: Does Covid mean the end of hugging strangers?
item.description: For years, people have stood on streets holding ‘FREE HUGS’ signs but has Covid ended the movement?

item.title: Australia whales: ‘Unbelievable’ super-group caught on film
item.description: A massive whale pod has been seen "bubble-net" feeding for the first time off Australia’s coast.

item.title: How grief has united an Israeli, and a Palestinian mother
item.description: Grief and the desire for peace has united a Palestinian and an Israeli mother who both lost sons.

item.title: The Brazilian doctor offering bogus Covid remedies for social media likes
item.description: Albert Dickson, an elected politician, says he is 'above all a doctor' and defends medical autonomy.

item.title: Covid: What do we know about global youth unemployment?
item.description: Young people have suffered from the economic consequences of Covid.

item.title: Italy's plummeting birth rate worsened by pandemic
item.description: Italy's birth rate is at its lowest since 1861 and Covid-19 has made it harder to start a family.

item.title: Hall And Oates: How You Make My Dreams became a streaming colossus
item.description: The 80s pop duo explain how You Make My Dreams became a streaming colossus.

item.title: The US socialite who gave it all up to become a Carmelite nun
item.description: Sister Mary Joseph gave the end of her life to God but her first 60 years were far from traditional.

item.title: Myanmar: The mysterious deaths of the NLD party officials
item.description: The deaths of officials from Aung San Suu Kyi's party has raised scrutiny of the military's actions.

item.title: Boundary review: Winners and losers from proposed changes
item.description: How does the proposed new electoral map for England square with the government's "levelling up" agenda?

item.title: Brexit: What is the Northern Ireland Protocol and why does it affect sausages?
item.description: Why are there now some border checks between Great Britain and Northern Ireland?

item.title: Increase in terrific female roles, says Winslet
item.description: The star also says she was adamant about not digitally altering her body for a recent sex scene.

item.title: French Open 2021: Rafael Nadal beats Diego Schwartzman in Paris
item.description: Defending champion Rafael Nadal reaches a record-extending 14th French Open semi-final after outlasting Argentina's Diego Schwartzman.

item.title: England have faced 'ugly truths' over offensive historical tweets - Root
item.description: Captain Joe Root says his side have faced up some "ugly truths" after a number of offensive historical tweets from England players were revealed.

item.title: An ignorant minority who need educating - Ferdinand on those that boo 'taking a knee'
item.description: The people booing England players taking a knee are an "ignorant minority" who need "educating", says former England captain Rio Ferdinand.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Olympics athletes to be monitored by GPS
item.description: Athletes at this summer's Olympics will be subject to GPS monitoring, says Tokyo 2020 organising committee chief Toshiro Muto.

item.title: Defending champion Swiatek beaten by Sakkari in French Open quarters
item.description: Maria Sakkari beats defending champion Iga Swiatek to reach her maiden Grand Slam semi-final at the French Open.

item.title: Euro 2020 and Covid: How can I watch with my friends?
item.description: Covid rules are making things a bit different for Euro 2020 spectators.

item.title: Covid: What do under-30s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: The vaccine rollout is now reaching younger adults. What do they need to know about getting jabbed?

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being surge tested for variants?
item.description: People who live, work or travel in various parts of the UK are being urged to get a Covid test.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The government is yet to decide whether to lift the remaining restrictions on 21 June

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: Foreign holidays are possible, but travellers must follow strict rules on their return.

item.title: Travel guide to Spain, Portugal, France and more holiday hotspots
item.description: What you need to know about travelling abroad to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: The vaccine is being offered to over-18s in Wales and Northern Ireland, over-25s in England and over-30s in Scotland.

item.title: Covid Indian variant: Where is it, how does it spread and is it more infectious?
item.description: The Indian variant is spreading in some parts of the country - how serious is it?

item.title: Covid-19: Could a third wave change 21 June plans in England?
item.description: Rising coronavirus cases have called the planned 21 June relaxing of rules in England into question.

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go... and who with?
item.description: Going abroad is not straightforward, so many people are opting to stay in the UK for their holidays.

item.title: Lockdown muscle loss: Five ways to get back in shape
item.description: Lockdown inactivity may have left people with weaker muscles - there are simple solutions.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid: How is Europe lifting lockdown restrictions?
item.description: A third Covid wave hit much of Europe hard but now gradually lockdowns are being eased.

item.title: Freddie Figgers: The millionaire tech inventor who was 'thrown away' as a baby
item.description: Entrepreneur Freddie Figgers says life has taught him that the important thing is people, not profits.

item.title: Valentina Petrillo: 'Better to be a slow happy woman than a fast unhappy man'
item.description: If Valentina Petrillo is selected for Italy's squad in Tokyo this year, she will be the first trans woman Paralympian.

item.title: The Motherload: How pandemic anger almost destroyed a mums' support group
item.description: Abusive messages from angry mums during lockdown almost caused the founder of The Motherload to close it down.

item.title: The children selling explicit videos on OnlyFans
item.description: British subscription site OnlyFans is failing to prevent underage users from selling and appearing in explicit videos, a BBC investigation has found.

item.title: Why Kim Jong-un is waging war on slang, jeans and foreign films
item.description: A sweeping new law makes the smuggling of foreign news, films or drama punishable by death.
